fields.physical_description:
Scrapbook of 26 pages bound in pale purple cloth covered in boards. Front cover blocked in black and gold with bird and flower motif and lettered in capitals 'Scraps'. Contains scraps, various greetings cards, and 30 examples of pressed seaweeds each sheet inscribed in ink with the botanical name and in some cases, other details relating to identification. Some items stuck in and others slotted into page through cuts in the paper. The book includes loose scraps:
E.645:2-1998 - sheet of shamrocks
E.645:3-1998 - envelope with Mrs Goodlake inscribed on the front
E.645:4-1998 - card, Building for the Great Exhibition of 1851
E.645:5-1998 - card, Interior of the Building for the Great Exhibition of 1851
E.645:6-1998 - card, Gelerts Grave
E.645:7-1998 - cut-out flowers
E.645:8-1998 - trade card for J Barber's, Ship Hotel
[Scrapbook] Scrapbook of 26 pages bound in pale purple cloth covered in boards. Front cover blocked in black and gold with bird and flower motif and lettered in capitals 'Scraps'.
[print] Shamrocks or four-leaf clovers? encapsulated in melinex.
[Envelope] Cream cut-paper envelope with intricate symmetrical design formed from pin-pricks, small holes and embossing. Encapsulated in melinex with two other scraps (E.645:4-E.645:5-1998).
[Greetings card] Greetings card with image of the Crystal Palace and crowds, set into an oval against a white background. Encapsulated in melinex with two other scraps (E.645:3-1998 and E.645:5-1998).
[Greetings card] Greetings card with image of the interior of The Crystal Palace and crowds and exhibits, set into an oval against a white background. Encapsulated in melinex with two other scraps (E.645:3-E645:4-1998).
[Greetings card] Greetings card with image of people in Victorian costume standing around Gelert's grave in a hilly landscape, with low wooden building in the background. The grave is a clump of trees and two rock forms surrounded by a metal fence. Encapsulated in melinex with two other scraps (E.645:7-E.645:8-1998).
[print] Cut-out and embossed colour print of a bunch of flowers. Encapsulated in melinex with two other scraps (E.645:6-1998 and E.645:8-1998).
[Trade card] Trade card for J. Barber's, Ship Hotel. A framed scene shows a riverside Hotel building with promenade and river on which are a number of different types of vessel, rowing boats, sailing ships, paddle steamer and sailing dinghy. People are walking along the river's edge, which is tree-lines. In the background can be seen trees, a building and windmill. A plan of Antwerp is on the back. Encapsulated in melinex with two other scraps (E.645:6-E.645:7-1998).

fields.public_access_description: This scrapbook is particularly interesting because in addition to the usual scraps and greetings cards it has 30 sheets of well-preserved pressed seaweeds, each specimen named. Pressed flowers are commonplace in such albums but seaweeds are more unusual. It reflects the interest in amateur botany that developed in the 19th century amongst women and children, and gives us a view of 19th century leisure pursuits and domestic pastimes. This scrapbook is also of interest in relation to the cyanotypes of algae and other plants by Anna Atkins, and the practice of illustrating botanical books on ferns, grasses, mosses, seaweeds with real pressed specimens rather in the manner of a herbarium.

fields.name: Great Exhibition of the Works of Industry of all Nations

fields.historical_context_note: It is a splendid example of the interest in amateur botany as a leisure pursuit and domestic pastime that developed in the 19th century, amongst women, and children.
